I want to like this change, and I love the idea of keystone runes, but something keeps tugging at the back of my mind. Runes have always been important to winning lane, and to me, they've always felt like very meaningful choices. If you look at professional player builds, or champion main builds, you'll see that some people run very strange runes to fill in gaps that their champion has, such as an {{champion:103}} Ahri who might run 5 percent attack speed in the mid lane to make her last hitting more fluid and reliable. Some people want to play with their luck, opting for a .93 crit chance mark instead of an attack damage one. 

  I'm truly afraid that, by making this change, you wont be able to fill in gaps that some champions tend to have as champions are constantly being changed, altered, revamped, redone, etc. Runes allowed players to fill in small little nerfs like a decreased base attack speed for a champ by sacrificing other runes in its stead. 

How does Riot plan to make this feel like its own unique system, separate from masteries, that still allow for an adequate amount of champion based customization(if they do)?

TL;DR  HALP!!
Riot please reply to this. Great question

I agree with the concerns voiced here, and have always considered my runes the reliable fallbacks for covering categorical niches. Goign support? I can take my page with mana regen,Ap, and armor; or my defense/hp/movespeed. offensive? I have another page that's lategame defenses with attack speed for champs who can bide their time, like Gnar and Irelia, or just flat AD with a touch of defense for Riven and Jhin. It's always felt like my runes were -MY- big contributions to the champions and my playstyle, lovingly crafted with the IP gained from hundreds of matches over many years. This new change makes it look like Materies Part 2, and gives limits to the amount you can raise a stat. 
Can we still, say, sacrifice the unique benefits of MR and Armor to pump our attack speed through the roof?

I also feel that this new system is a little polarized. Like you said, runes are a way to tune your champions stats to give them the best chance at whatever you plan to do with them. I feel as though riot is trying to peel back the tactics part of the game for a more flashy, categorized type of game.

Starting items (dBlade and one pot, for example) -500g, total 0g

Potion #1 -50g AND -50g lending fee, total -100g

Potion #2 -50g AND -50g lending fee, total -200g

You guys are aware that no matter what you do, there's always going to be an optimal setup that use a champion's strength to its maximum potential, right?

We expect some portion of runes to optimize out on specific champions. e.g. Nasus hooks very strongly into CDR and Intelligence is a fit here. In this way, you're right. These things do take awhile to solve out though, and that discovery process is still ongoing and being disrupted for many champions even with the current setup.

I don't believe the "no matter what you do" statement is correct though. "Optimal" can be meaningfully changed by situation, such as who your allies are or who your enemies are. e.g. In the last article, we showed Overheal - which gets MUCH stronger when you have a healer on your team, and more so in your lane. Switching to overheal causes other decisions to switch as well, and this is what the "splashing" is all about here. To get overheal, you have to also change your other splash rune choice.

Don't get me wrong, I believe this to be for the bettering of the game, and I am really excited for Runges Reforged :D I'm just skeptical about the impact of _"Picking a Playstyle"_ as I believe champions will always have an optimal way to be played simply based on their kits, and instances where you may wanna trade off your optimal Rune for a situational one will be the exception, not the rule.

I actually think Keystones right now show this trend fairly well too, where the best way to play something like Kah is with Thunderlord's. There have been changes and buffs to other offensive Keystones, but anyone hoping to get the best of Kah and be competitive with him will always pick Thunderlord's, and so far I don't really see how Runes reforged will be that big of a difference where this won't occur. Sure, one Kah may use Battle Trance instead of Double Edged Sword, but you **still** will take Thunderlord's regardless.

Why would Kog not want Berserk every game? He's at his best when blasting baddies with high ASPD in the late game, and any other option would just detract from his most powerful form. Playing Kog'Maw to not be this late game powerhouse just means playing Kog as a lesser version of himself, and I don't think anyone who wants to main Kog would want that.

I just feel there's always going to be a Rune that will improve a champion's kit the best over any other option simply based on the kits themselves. Because in the end, current masteries/runes and then Runes Reforged are a pre-game setup that aims to optimize a champion's kit so he or she can do what they're designed to do the very best.

I dont think thats totally true. Every player has their own playstyle, and based on that playstyle individual players might get a better payoff with a different rune set than the "optimal" one. Sure if a player had total mastery of a champion in the exact way that champ was designed, there's an optimal page, but theres a different optimal page for a player playing an aggressive nautilus support rather than more defensive, right?
